key_points.point_content: Innovation is motivated by expected private returns ensured by intellectual property rights, increasing market demand, user initiatives, and influenced by laws and economic environments creating incentives and disincentives for innovation.

Innovation results from advances in knowledge, new technological opportunities, diffusion of general purpose technologies, and progress driven by recent advances in component technologies and materials.

Innovation can be driven by negative pressures such as factor-price inducement, declines in profits, problem solving activity overcoming imbalances and technical obstacles, and discrete incentives from history-specific problems and opportunities including economic, environmental, social problems.

Innovation is influenced by economic mechanisms, growth prospects, policy change, economic crisis, social upheaval, and distinct industrial patterns where problemistic search is salient in medium-high technology industries and technological opportunities dominate in high-tech industries.

Innovation is a search process under complexity and uncertainty, where heuristics and focusing devices help identify problems, market opportunities, technological opportunities, and institutionalized search paths.
Innovation drives economic growth, but the factors driving innovation are not fully understood.

Most scholars see new scientific knowledge as providing focus and capability for developing new products and processes (linear model), but this model has been largely abandoned except in some fields like biomedicine; in most industries invention does not rely on new science, with biotech as an exception.

The Silicon Valley model fits innovation better than the linear model in most technology fields, where innovations are incremental, cumulative, and progress can be rapid; rapid technological advance occurs notably in biotech and information processing.

Broadening innovation involves making university research more focused on creating bases for technological advance in needed areas, and technological innovations can be formed by fresh combinations of existing elements independent of scientific advances.

The frequency of citations of scientific publications in patents is used to measure the importance of the science-based model but has limitations; different industries rely differently on patents, trade secrets, and scientific papers, affecting measures of science's contribution to innovation.

There is a distinction between mission-oriented (big science for big problems) and diffusion-oriented (broad capacity for technological change) national research strategies; US policy since the 1980s includes experiments to foster a more mission-oriented approach to federal R&D investments.

Better measurement tools and broader definitions of innovation are needed to assess its total economic impact; free innovation, where innovators create new products or processes for personal needs and share them freely, is an important but currently unmeasured part of innovation.
Mission-focused innovation requires decisions on missions, critical research areas, and goals, raising questions about funding and the role of basic research.

Technology-driven innovation can provide new challenges that advance science, exemplified by the invention of the transistor; both top-down government policy shifts and bottom-up changes from researchers and institutions can lead to high-impact research and innovation.

Nurturing talent is a key driver of innovation, as individuals with natural talent can lead innovation if their talent is nurtured; managing creativity through acknowledgement and reward encourages further innovation; building strong relationships within teams and between managers and employees boosts creativity and idea sharing; encouraging a culture of innovation by making it a regular and natural occurrence drives constant innovation.

Innovation is the most important driver of macroeconomics today and brings ideas to life, making their mark on the world; businesses must come up with new ideas rather than settle for marginally better ideas, as 'Better doesn't work anymore. Different does.'

Four types of people drive innovation: inventors, entrepreneurs, extreme individual achievers, and super mentors; hiring top talent based on natural talents rather than experience drives innovation; employee engagement is highly related to the ability to innovate; incubating employee ideas in relaxed environments with knowledge, technique, and motivation fosters innovation.

Managers play a key role in turning creativity into innovation by inspiring and connecting employees to action; hiring and retaining A-level managers improves retention and performance of top talent; the quality of the relationship between a manager and an employee affects the ability to leverage innovation, with bad relationships killing innovation.

Understanding and connecting with customers is essential to developing and enacting innovative ideas; selecting leaders with the right talent profile and succession planning based on data drives innovation and company growth.

Make innovation part of everyone’s job and provide the skills and tools for innovation; develop and use structured innovation processes that everyone can use; innovation goes beyond products to include services, processes, or channels; create teams that support innovation with values like curiosity, humility, and tenacity; welcome new ideas to generate more ideas and use tools to evaluate them effectively; leverage diversity by understanding strengths and differences to accelerate innovation; build a culture of innovation supporting people, processes, policies, and climate; show that innovation is important through training, time, leadership, and rewards; design physical spaces that foster creative collaboration and innovation.

Fund innovation even during tough economic times to maintain focus and drive change; leaders want more innovation in their cultures and know they can’t play it safe, which requires employees to take chances and not be afraid to fail; most organizations encourage safe behavior by rewarding straightforward successes and punishing failures, which discourages risk-proj-t-3jM9g14yGtzozJKYlWdtPW3nCuv8MoCKAkJPlQS7cBygKF6ur3tLm-pGfCEHxg5Jkk7lohYET3BlbkFJYfa6MImXvTLilGultWkvXMY8Cdcr6lofi2WkCxxuTZr37mtK8de78smZCWM3yLF6PiNIeNWEoA.

Gallup’s research shows only 13% of employees are engaged at work, partly because they are limited in their ability to be innovative and creative; more than 50% of respondents in an Accenture survey reported feeling too busy or blocked at work to think up and propose new, innovative ideas.

Leaders have enormous influence in setting the tone for how risk taking will be tolerated and how failure will be managed; developing innovation-friendly policies like Fed Ex days, Google's 20% time, or 3M's 15% time creates space and time to innovate; communicating and celebrating new ideas and positive failures encourages innovation and learning; trying out innovative ideas through rapid-cycle experiments helps test new ways of working without immediate full implementation; being realistic about the appetite for failure and allowing for smart failures is essential to promoting risk taking and innovation.
